member.summary: Occurs when the element receives focus.
member.remarks: Focused event is raised whenever the VisualElement receives focus. This event is not bubbled through the Xamarin.Forms stack and is received directly from the native control. This event is emitted by the IsFocusedProperty setter.

member.name: M:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.GetSizeRequest(System.Double,System.Double)
member.param: The available width that a parent element can allocated to a child. Value will be between 0 and double.PositiveInfinity.
The available height that a parent element can allocated to a child. Value will be between 0 and double.PositiveInfinity.
member.summary: Returns the of the element. Calling this method begins the measure pass of a layout cycle.
member.returns: A which contains a requested size and a minimum size.
member.remarks: Calling GetSizeRequest causes a measure pass to occur for the subtree of elements it is called on. It is ideal to only call GetSizeRequest when needed as excessive calls can negatively impact the performance of your app. Overriding GetSizeRequest should only be done if you want to ignore Width/HeightRequest. More likely a subclass would wish to override .

member.name: P:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.Height
member.summary: Gets the current rendered height of this element. This is a read-only bindable property.
member.value: The renderered height of this element.
member.remarks: The height of an element is set during the Layout phase.

member.name: F:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.HeightProperty
member.summary: Identifies the Height bindable property.

member.name: P:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.HeightRequest
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired height override of this element.
member.value: The height this element desires to be.
member.remarks: HeightRequest does not immediately change the Bounds of a VisualElement, however setting the HeightRequest will change the result of calls to GetSizeRequest, which will in turn modify the final size the element receives during a layout cycle.

member.name: F:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.HeightRequestProperty
member.summary: Backing store for the HeightRequest property.

member.name: P:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.InputTransparent
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this element should be involved in the user interaction cycle. This is a bindable property.
member.value: if the element and its children should receive input; if neither the element nor its children should receive input and should, instead, pass inputs to the elements that are visually behind the current visual element. Default is .
member.remarks: Setting InputTransparent is not the same as setting IsEnabled to false. Setting InputTransparent only disables inputs and instead causes them to be passed to the that is visually behind the element. Usually, this is the parent of the element. The value of the property is inherited by a visual element's child elements.

member.name: P:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.MinimumHeightRequest
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which overrides the minimum height the element will request during layout.
member.value: The minimum height the element requires. Default value is -1.

remarks.para: MinimumHeightRequest is used to override the results of a call to by setting the minimum height property. This causes overflow handling to shrink this element to its minimum height before elements who do not have a minimum size set.

member.name: P:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.Opacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the opacity value applied to the element when it is rendered. This is a bindable property.
member.value: The opacity value. Default opacity is 1.0. Values will be clamped between 0 and 1 on set.

remarks.para: The opacity value has no effect unless IsVisible is . Opacity is inherited down the element hierarchy. If a parent has 0.5 opacity, and a child has 0.5 opacity, the child will render with an effective 0.25 opacity. Setting opacity to 0 has undefined behavior with input elements.
The following example sets the opacity of a layout to 0.5 and the opacity of one of its children to 0.5, making the child 25% opaque.

member.name: F:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.OpacityProperty

member.name: P:Xamarin.Forms.VisualElement.Resources
member.summary: Gets or sets the local resource dictionary.
member.value: The current resource dictionary, where resources are stored by key.

remarks.para: In XAML, resource dictionaries are filled with key/value pairs that are specified in XML and consequently created at run time. The keys in the resource dictionary are specified with the x:Key attribute of the XML tag for the type to create. An object of that type is created, and is initialized with the property and field values that are specified either by additional attributes or by nested tags, both of which, when present are simply string representations of the property or field names. The object is then inserted into the for the enclosing type at runtime.

example.para: For example, the XAML below, taken from the XAML for Xamarin.Forms series, creates a resource dictionary that contains object constants that can be used for any objects that are added to the surrounding :
example.code:
<ContentPage.Resources> <ResourceDictionary> <LayoutOptions x:Key="horzOptions" Alignment="Center" />
<LayoutOptions x:Key="vertOptions" Alignment="Center" Expands="True" /> </ResourceDictionary> </ContentPage.Resources>
example.para: Note that the above snippet is only valid when nested within a <ContentPage>...</ContentPage> tag pair. Within that pair, the app developer can use both of the horzOptions and vertOptions keys to specify values for properties of type by using the "{...}" static resource syntax. The short example below, also taken from the XAML for Xamarin.Forms series, illustrates this syntax:
example.code: <Button Text="Do this!" HorizontalOptions="{StaticResource horzOptions}" VerticalOptions="{StaticResource vertOptions}" BorderWidth="3" Rotation="-15" TextColor="Red" Font="Large" />
example.para: Resource dictionaries and their associated XML provide the application developer with a convenient method to reuse code inside the XAML compile-time and run-time engines.

remarks.para: With visual state objects, developers can associate novel visual state names with a list of property setters that cause the control to represent that state. member.summary: Indicates that the action key will send a next action.

member.summary: Indicates that no UI will be displayed for custom actions.

member.summary: Indicates that no UI will be shown for extracted text.

member.summary: Indicates that the editor UI should not go fullscreen.
